trial_identification.studytitle: Randomised controlled trial comparing ligation of the intersphicteric fistula tract vs advancement flap for complex anorectal fistulas requiring intial seton drainage
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does ligation of the intersphicteric fistula tract provide at least a 40% improvement in recurrence rate compared with anorectal advancement flap: A randomised controlled trial comparing ligation of the intersphicteric fistula tract with advancement flap for complex anorectal fistulas requiring intial seton drainage

conditions.healthcondition: Complex anorectal fistulas where setons were previously inserted because fistulotomy was deemed to risk significant incontinence

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions: A probe was inserted into the tract an incision then made in the intersphincteric groove and the fistula tract identified in this space. Once the tract is dissected free it is encircled and the probe removed. The fistula tract is then divided and transfixed both sides with 3/0 PDS. The external opening is left open the internal opening is curetted and closed with a vicryl suture. This is a single intervention. Operation duration is approximately 10 minutes.
interventions.comparator: A full thickness flap consisting of mucosa and submucosa and the internal anal sphincter was mobilised from the level of the dentate line cephalad. The base of the flap was at least twice as wide as its apex to ensure adequate blood supply to the distal end. The fistula tract was curetted and the mucosa of the internal sphincter opening excised. The edge of the flap was advanced onto the dentate line and sutured without tension over the internal opening using vicryl. This is a single intervention. Operation duration is approximately 40 minutes.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To determine if ligation of the intersphicteric fistula tract provides at least a 40% improvement in recurrence rate over anorectal advancement flap for complex anorectal fistulas after initial seton drainage. This outcome will be assessed by clinical examination, history and if required MRI and ultrasound.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Patients were reviewed in clinics at weeks 2, 4 and 16 then annually thereafter.

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At each clinical and history interview: at weeks 2, 4 and 16 then annually thereafter

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Bowel function: return to normal healthy bowel function
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At two weeks postoperatively by interview

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Time taken to resume normal activities

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Pre and one month post operatively by an independent research nurse using using the Cleveland Clinic Florida Fecal Incontinence Score(0-20, 0=continent)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients with transsphincteric or complex fistulas were entered into the study. Fistulas were classified as complex if any of the following were present: tract crossing more than 30% to 50% of the external sphincter, anterior fistula in a woman, multiple tracts, recurrent fistula, pre-existing incontinence or Crohns disease.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients with Crohns disease were excluded

trial_design.concealment: The study arm was placed in a sealed opaque envelope with the participant identification number on the front and given to the surgeon prior to surgery.
trial_design.sequence: Independent unrestricted parallel randomization was performed prior to study commencement using a computer-generated sequence.
trial_design.designfeatures: Only participants were blinded as to study group.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A new method of treating difficult anorectal fistulae was compared with the traditionally accepted approach. Management of this condition is known to have a relatively high recurrence rate. Treatment also carries a risk of faecal incontinence. Our results show after seton drainage of infection the new method ligation of the intersphicteric fistula tract (LIFT) is at least as good as traditional anorectal advancement flap method with regard to recurrences.
